Award.AwardTitle: Do neuropeptides shape alternative mating tactics and reproductive success through effects on memory?
Award.AbstractNarration:
A clear understanding of the neural mechanisms that govern how memory influences reproductive decisions will reveal much about the basic neurobiology that shapes decision-making. Mating and reproductive decisions are among the most important choices an individual will face. To this end, an individual must take stock of the current state of the social context in which it finds itself. This includes knowing with whom and where mating opportunities are to be found. Unfortunately, the influence of social and spatial memory on how individuals in a population tend to mate (e.g., with one or multiple partners, or a mating system) is often ignored. Moreover, we know virtually nothing about the ways the brain modulates these decisions or how memory and mate choice decisions are related. This project will use prairie voles to investigate how expression of two neuroendocrine systems known to be important in social / spatial memory and monogamous reproductive decision making, namely, oxytocin and vasopressin, modulate complex social behavior to shape reproductive choices.

The project will study reproductive choices in the prairie vole, a species that can switch between monogamous and non-monogamous mating tactics, with the aims to determine (1) whether or not mating decisions in natural conditions and laboratory performance in memory tests relate to each other, and (2) how oxytocin or vasopressin in the hippocampus and the retrosplenial cortex, regions implicated in spatial and social cognition, shape these behaviors. The working hypothesis is that nonapeptide neuromodulation governs socio-spatial memory, which in turn, predisposes animals to succeed at either a monogamous or a non-monogamous mating tactic. This hypothesis will be tested using a combination of natural living conditions, behavioral assays to assess social and spatial cognition, radio-tracking to monitor extent of home range and social interactions, DNA sampling to assess mating tactic, radiography to measure oxytocin and vasopressin 1A receptor density, and intra-hippocampal or -retrosplenial delivery of slow-release receptor antisense oligonucleotides to knock down oxytocin and vasopressin 1A receptors in these brain structures. In the process of completing this project, students at all levels will be trained with a broad range of skills that will prepare them to begin competitive careers in biomedical research, medicine, or higher education and academics. The PI will also continue his strong record of promoting research experiences and professional development in students from underrepresented groups. It is essential to understand the influences on behavior under simulated and natural contexts if we are to know how complex behaviors are produced.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A clear understanding of the neural mechanisms that govern how memory influences reproductive decisions will reveal much about the neurobiology that shapes decision-making. Mating decisions are among the most important choices an individual will face. An individual must evaluate the social context in which it finds itself. This includes knowing with whom and where mating opportunities are to be found. The influence of social and spatial memory on how individuals mate is often ignored. Moreover, we know virtually nothing about the ways the brain modulates these decisions or how memory and mate choice decisions are related. This project has investigated how expression of two neuroendocrine systems known to be important in social / spatial memory and monogamous reproductive decision making (oxytocin and vasopressin) modulate complex social behavior to shape reproductive choices. 

The project focused on a monogamous rodent, the prairie vole, to determine if mating decisions in natural conditions relate to laboratory performance in memory tests, and how oxytocin or vasopressin shape these behaviors. This project has produced several important discoveries. To date, we have published 9 papers in leading journals (with several more to come). PI, postdocs, grad students and undergrad students have delivered 12 presentations at international meetings, and the PI has given 16 invited lectures at prestigious universities or meetings worldwide. Notable results include, but are not limited to, the following.

(1) Based on theoretical modeling and behavioral observation, we have identified three distinct alternative mating tactics (non-monogamous 'wanderers', monogamous and socially faithful 'true residents', and monogamous but socially promiscuous 'roving residents'). We are the first to show that pairbonded males vary in the degree of space use and spatial fidelity, such that some monogamous males engage in intermediate patters of space use that closely resemble non-monogamous (wandering) males. This greatly modifies our understanding of this classic animal model for human love and attachment, and wills serve as a platform for a deeper understanding of the factors that lead to social promiscuity. 

(2) Our experiments have supported our hypothesis that nonapeptides and neural structures associated with spatial memory are important for differences in mating tactics. For example, intranasal vasopressin delivered chronically to developing ‘adolescent’ male prairie voles enhances spatial memory. We have promoted the novel idea that nonapeptides acting in the hippocampus (HPC) modulate the ability of males and females to assess the socio-spatial landscape, thereby enabling animals to identify the best contexts to form bonds or remain single. We have demonstrated that males performed better in a spatial memory test compared to females, an unexpected difference for monogamous species. Interestingly, although we found no structural sex differences in the HPC, males had more HPC oxytocin receptor than females, suggesting that performance may be regulated by sub-cellular mechanisms within the hippocampus. Previous studies have demonstrated that oxytocin has amnesic effects in other forms of memory, and reduced receptors seen in males presumably reduces these effects, thereby improving spatial memory. Our results suggest an expanded role for oxytocin and vasopressin, supporting the overarching hypothesis that nonapeptides function in part to integrate social and spatial information. 

(3) We assessed the influence of a functional or non-functional HPC on male reproductive decisions under natural field conditions. Our results suggest that non-functional HPC promotes socially promiscuous behavior by males, and might decrease bond strength. Dysfunctional HPCs shifted the proportion of monogamous (true) resident males toward becoming non-monogamous wanderers. These data support our hypothesis that HPC function should be associated with monogamous behavior and that the HPC contributes to male reproductive decision-making. In addition to providing clarity on the mechanisms that shape mating tactics, this study expands the presumed function of HPC from context-dependent memory to encompass a broader role for the HPC in modulating behavior with direct fitness consequences. This work has begun to redefine how we think about the important components of mating systems away from a focus on bonding, parental care, and territory defense, and highlighting cognitive abilities that facilitate the assessment of the socio-spatial landscape. 

Students at all levels have be trained with a broad range of skills that prepared them to begin competitive careers in biomedical research, medicine, or higher education. This project has provided an opportunity to train nearly 30 undergraduate and high school students, the majority of whom have perused STEM careers. Most were women (66%) and many (33%) came from disenfranchised or disadvantaged backgrounds. Through our efforts, we have broadened the base of human resources that exist in our field and beyond. We have participated in several workshop and professional development opportunities to extend our reach to train the next generation of leaders at international meetings, and local events (e.g., programs promoting STEM careers for young girls), injecting excitement for neuroscience in elementary schools, and working with undergraduates in casual environments to coach them on decisions that impact their professional lives.
